questions.text: A pathologist examines a surgically resected pituitary tumour under a microscope. The tumour comprises sheets of monomorphic, round to polygonal cells with central nuclei and sparse to absent reticulin network. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following statements about the cells in the distal tubule and cortical collecting tubule is NOT correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Principal cells are responsible for sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion.

options.label: B
options.text: Type A intercalated cells secrete hydrogen ions and reabsorb bicarbonate

options.label: C
options.text: Amiloride and triamterene act as potassium-sparing diuretics by blocking sodium channels in principal cells

options.label: D
options.text: Spironolactone and eplerenone increase sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in principal cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Spironolactone and eplerenone increase sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in principal cells
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Principal Cells

Intercalated Cells

Main Function

Sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion (Option A)

Acid-base regulation

Proportion

60-70% of cells in collecting tubules and ducts.

30-40% of cells in collecting tubules and ducts.

Types

                                -
  • Type A
  • Type B

Key Processes

Na+ reabsorption via Na+ channels

K+ secretion via K+ channels

Water reabsorption (regulated by ADH).

Type A: (Option B)

  • H+ secretion
  • HCO3- reabsorption

Type B:

  • HCO3- secretion
  • H+ reabsorption

Key Transporters

Na+-K+ ATPase pump in basolateral membrane.

Type A

  • H+-ATPase (apical
  • H+-K+-ATPase (apical)
  • Cl--HCO3- exchanger (basolateral)

Type B:

  • H+-ATPase (basolateral)
  • Pendrin (Cl--HCO3- exchanger, apical)

Hormonal Regulation

Responsive to aldosterone

Not primarily regulated by aldosterone.

Diuretic Targets

Primary targets for potassium-sparing diuretics

Not primary targets for most diuretics.

Specific Diuretics
  • Spironolactone and eplerenone (aldosterone antagonists)
  • Amiloride and triamterene (Na+ channel blockers) (Option C)

Not specifically targeted by common diuretics.

Effect of K+-sparing Diuretics

Decrease Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion

Minimal direct effect.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with complaints of persistent lower abdominal pain and fever. She had a copper-releasing intrauterine device inserted nine months ago for contraception. She has multiple sexual partners. On examination, she appears uncomfortable, and her abdomen is tender to palpation in the lower quadrants. Pelvic examination reveals no visible IUD strings. Her vital signs show a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). What is the most likely complication associated with this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Side effects of IUDs

Bleeding
  • Most common side effect; physiological bleeding resolves in 1-3 months.
  • Iron supplementation may be needed.
  • Persistent bleeding despite treatment may necessitate IUD removal.

Pain
  • Most common cause for removal
  • Managed with analgesics.
  • Resolves in 3 months.
  • Severe pain may indicate uterine perforation (rare).

Pelvic inflammatory disease (Option C)
  • Presents with fever, abdominal pain, and discharge.
  • Treatment involves broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • IUD removal if no improvement.
  • 3rd generation of IUD is protective against IUD.

Uterine perforation (Option B)
  • Rare complications linked to immediate postpartum insertion or poor technique.
  • 1st generation IUDs are associated with a higher risk of perforation.

Failure of contraception ➜ pregnancy
  • Least pregnancies are reported with MIRENA.
  • If a woman requests an induced abortion – legally allowed.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are visible:
    • Pull the thread and continue pregnancy.
    • Explain the risk of spontaneous abortion or congenital anomalies.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are not visible:
    • Uterus examination for any complications. Evacuation of uterus if any complication is identified.
    • If no complication identified , pregnancy can be continued after removal of IUD if the woman desires with increased risk of spontaneous abortion and pre term labour. 

Ectopic pregnancy (Option D)
  • Recognized by lower abdominal pain, dark vaginal bleeding, or amenorrhea.
  • Women at high risk should avoid IUDs.

Expulsion
(Option A)
  • Typically occurs within weeks of insertion or during menstruation.
  • Higher risk in young, nulliparous, postpartum women or using 1st generation IUDs

Migration of IUD
  • Rarely causes intestinal obstruction.
  • Diagnosed via X-ray imaging if suspected.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a 12-day history of a missed period and a positive pregnancy test undergoes a procedure to empty her uterus. Identify the instrument used in this early pregnancy management procedure:
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
(Option B)

Menstrual Regulation (Option D)

Use

Uterine evacuation up to 12 weeks of pregnancy for medical termination.

Aspiration of endometrial cavity within 14 days of missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle.

Instrument used

MVA Syringe: Has double pinchable valves

MR Syringe: Has a single pinchable valve

Anesthesia

Local anesthesia

Sedation or paracervical block

Indications

Medical termination of pregnancy, incomplete/missed abortion, molar pregnancy, blighted ovum, endometrial sampling/biopsy.

Missed period, failed abortion, molar pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy exclusion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice from a common bile duct stone, confirmed by elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase, underwent successful stone extraction via ERCP. Post-procedure, the patient received education on bile flow regulation. Which of the following is not associated with bile synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Hormonal Regulation
  • Secretin (Option B): Stimulates the secretion of a watery, bicarbonate-rich solution by epithelial cells in the bile ducts.
  • Cholecystokinin (CCK): Induces gallbladder contraction and relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi, facilitating the release of concentrated bile into the duodenum in response to fatty foods.

Neural Regulation
  • Vagal Stimulation: Promotes weak gallbladder contraction.
  • Enteric Nervous System: Nerve fibres in the intestine stimulate gallbladder motility and secretion.

Feedback Regulation
  • It is influenced by the presence of fats and acids in the duodenum.
  • Bile salts are the most potent regulators of Bile synthesis, which is regulated by the feedback mechanism. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Quintero staging system for Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)?

options.label: A
options.text: Stage I is characterized by absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery of the donor twin.

options.label: B
options.text: Stage II is defined by the presence of polyhydramnios in the recipient twin and anhydramnios in the donor twin.

options.label: C
options.text: Stage III involves critically abnormal Doppler findings in one or both twins.

options.label: D
options.text: Stage V indicates the presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins.

questions.correct_answer: C. Stage III involves critically abnormal Doppler findings in one or both twins.
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Stage I (Option A ruled out)

Polyhydramnios in the recipient twin (deepest vertical pocket ≥8 cm) and oligohydramnios in the donor twin (deepest vertical pocket ≤2 cm), with a visible bladder in the donor twin.

Stage II (Option B ruled out)

The donor twin's bladder is not visible on ultrasound, indicating severe oligohydramnios.

Stage III

Critically abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, reversed flow in the ductus venosus, or pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein in one or both twins

Stage IV

Presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins, indicating severe fetal compromise

Stage V (Option D ruled out)

Demise of one or both twins

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of progressive weakness that started in his legs after returning from his international trip. Today he cannot get up from bed and is having hand weakness. On examination, distal arreflexia is noted with power grade 1/5 for muscles at all joints of lower limbs and 3/5 for upper limbs. CSF study shows cytoalbuminological dissociation. Which criteria are used for diagosis of this condition?

A 45-year-old patient reports difficulty hearing in the Right ear. Pure tone audiometry is done and the result is given in the image below. Given the audiometric findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Air Conduction (AC)

Bone Conduction (BC)

Frequency Range

125 - 8000 Hz

250 - 4000 Hz

Indicates

Overall hearing sensitivity

Cochlear function

Normal Ear
  • Both AC and BC thresholds are within the normal range (Within 20db in all frequencies)
  • No significant A-B gap

Conductive Hearing Loss
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated (poorer hearing) compared to normal.
  • BC Thresholds: Within normal limits.
  • A-B Gap (>20db): Significant

Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL)

(Option B)
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated to the same degree as AC.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal or absent

Presbycusis

(Option C)
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated, particularly in high frequencies.
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated with greater loss in higher frequencies.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal
  • Downsloping

Meniere’s Disease

(Option D)
  • Upsloping
  • A-B Gap: Typically minimal

  • inflammation without tissue invasion.

 
  • Giardia trophozoites on biopsy are often described as resembling "falling leaves"

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with right lower quadrant abdominal pain and is diagnosed with acute appendicitis. The surgical team plans to perform an appendectomy. Which of the following correctly represents the type of Incision used in appendicectomy? a-Lanz b-Rutherford Morrison c-McBurney’s d-Paramedian
questions.explanation:
McBurney's incision
  • Centered on McBurney's point, perpendicular to the umbilical ASIS line
  • Junction of lateral 1/3 from umbilicus & medial 2/3 from ASIS
  • McBurney's point corresponds to the base of the appendix
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Aka Grid iron incision / McArthur incision

Lanz incision

Placed transversely 2 cm below the umbilicus on the line joining the midpoint of the clavicle to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Cosmetically better incision
  • Aka Modified McBurney's incision / Rocky Davis incision / Bikini incision (good cosmetic appearance)

Rutherford-Morrison incision
  • Extension of McBurney's incision for retrocecal appendicitis
  • Upward & laterally by cutting conjoint tendon
  • Muscle cutting incision
  • Preferred for retrocecal appendix

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presenting with persistent right ear fullness, hearing loss, and pressure particularly during flights is suspected of having Eustachian tube blockage. During rhinoscopy, a structure labelled as X in the image below is noted. Identify this structure.
questions.explanation:
Boundaries

Relations

Roof

Formed by basisphenoid and basiocciput.

Posterior wall
  • C1 vertebra covered by prevertebral muscles and fascia
  • The roof and the posterior wall merge gradually with one another.

Floor
  • It is formed by the soft palate anteriorly but is deficient posteriorly.
  • The nasopharynx connects to the oropharynx (nasopharyngeal isthmus).

Anterior wall
  • Formed by posterior nasal apertures or choanae.
  • Posterior ends of nasal turbinates and meatuses are seen.

Lateral wall

  • Eustachian tube
  • Torus tubarius: A cushion-like elevation that borders the Eustachian tube from above and behind. (Option B)
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller: A recess above and behind the torus tubarius (the most common site for carcinoma origin).
  • Salpingopharyngeal fold: A ridge extends from the lower end of the torus tubarius to the lateral pharyngeal wall.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a chronic cough productive of copious sputum. He reports frequent respiratory infections over the past several years. Physical examination reveals digital clubbing and coarse crackles on auscultation. An HRCT is done and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Identify the correct option.
Which of the following is the most common type of radiolucent renal stone?
questions.explanation:
Stone Type

Features

Image

Calcium Oxalate
  • The most common type of stone (60–85% of all stones) ; Radiopaque
  • Associated with hypercalciuria, hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, and hypocitraturia
  • Types: monohydrate (dumbbell shaped) , dihydrate (envelope shaped)

 


 

Calcium Phosphate
  • Pure calcium phosphate stones are rare
  • Types include apatite and brushite stones
  • Apatite stones are seen with infection; brushite stones are associated with distal renal tubular acidosis

Struvite
  • Aka staghorn calculi / Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4+, Phosphate)
  • Radiopaque
  • Infection stones that form in alkaline urine due to urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, Enterobacter)

Cystine
  • Radiopaque, Constitute approximately 1% of stones
  • Result from cystinuria, an autosomal recessive inherited disease that causes decreased reabsorption of cystine
  • Very hard stones due to disulfide bonds

Uric Acid
  • Radiolucent
  • Promoted by hyperuricosuria, which can be caused by conditions like gout and myeloproliferative disorders
  • Precipitates in acidic urine and remains soluble in alkaline urine

questions.text: A 15 year old male presents to the ED after experiencing a brief episode of syncope. He reports occasional palpitations and dizziness. questions.text: A 35 year old man visits the clinic with a persistent cough and fever lasting for more than 2 weeks. He also reports experiencing night sweats and significant weight loss over the past month. Sputum smear tests or radiological tests are not yet done. According to the new terminologies in NTEP, how should this patient's case be categorized?
questions.explanation:
Category

Description

Criteria/Features

Presumptive TB Case
  • Used in place of TB suspect.
  • Individuals showing symptoms suggestive of TB but not yet confirmed.
  • Cough, Fever, Night sweats +- Weight loss > 2 weeks

Clinically Diagnosed TB Case

(Option A)
  • Sputum negative but with high clinical suspicion of TB.
  • Used in place of Sputum negative TB case. (Option C)
  • Persistent symptoms despite negative sputum smear
  • High clinical suspicion based on symptoms, radiological and histological features

Bacteriologically Confirmed TB Case
  • Biological specimen is positive for sputum AFB and/or CBNAAT.
  • Used in place of Sputum positive TB case.
  • Positive sputum smear for AFB
  • Positive CBNAAT test confirming the presence of TB bacteria

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a newly diagnosed left-sided breast mass on routine mammography. Core needle biopsy shows the following findings. Further molecular study revealed the involvement of the CDH1 gene. Which of the following statements are incorrect concerning this type of breast cancer? 1) Increased E-cadherin expression is observed in tumor cells. 2) Minimal desmoplasia and fibrosis were observed on microscopy. 3) A contralateral breast examination is usually required due to bilateral involvement. 4) It is associated with a poor prognosis compared to other types of breast cancer. 5) Metastatic spread affects leptomeninges and retroperitoneum.

An elderly male diabetic patient came with loss of vision in the left eye associated with pain in the left eye. On examination, the left eye appears red, and visual acuity- Perception of light+ and IOP is raised in the same eye. The patient gives history of blurring and diminution of vision for the past 1 year. The slit lamp examination is given below. Choose the correct diagnosis and appropriate pathophysiology for this patient.
questions.correct_answer: C. Phacolytic glaucoma - Secondary open-angle glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Feature

Phacomorphic Glaucoma

Phacolytic Glaucoma

Pathogenesis
  • Intumescent cataract blocks the pupil.
  • this pushes the iris forward,
  • blocking the anterior chamber angle,
  • leading to angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract clogs the trabecular meshwork.

Causes
  • Intumescent cataract (mature cataract)
  • Anterior subluxation of lens
  • Spherophakia
  • Hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract
  • Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by lens proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms are similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Shallow anterior chamber.
  • Ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and swollen cataract is visible.
  • Closed anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.
  • Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to high IOP.
  • Deep anterior chamber.
  • Open anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.

Management
  • Medical Treatment: IV mannitol, systemic acetazolamide, topical beta-blockers.
  • Laser Iridotomy: To relieve angle closure.
  • Surgical Treatment: Cataract extraction with PCIOL implantation.
  • Medical Therapy: To lower IOP.
  • Surgical Treatment: Extraction of the hypermature cataract and PCIOL implantation.

questions.text: Identify the type of tissue shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Skeletal Muscle

Cardiac Muscle

Smooth Muscle

Longitudinal Section:

  • Fibers are long, parallel, and non-branching.
  • Characteristic transverse striations are visible.
  • Multiple flat nuclei located at the periphery.
  • Fibers are separated by connective tissue (Epimysium, perimysium, endomysium).

Transverse Section:

  • Fibers appear as irregularly round structures with peripheral nuclei.
  • Muscle fibers are grouped into numerous fascicles.
  • Myofibrils appear as small dots within fibers at higher magnification.

 
  • Composed of individual cells with centrally placed nuclei.
  • Displays transverse striations.
  • Clear perinuclear halo around the nucleus.
  • Cells are separated by intercalated discs (transverse lines).
  • Fibers exhibit branching.
  • Blood vessels are present.
  • Loose connective tissue is seen above and below muscle layers.

Longitudinal Section:

  • Fibers are spindle-shaped with tapering ends.
  • Centrally located elongated nucleus.
  • No visible striations.

Transverse Section:

  • Spindle-shaped cells are cut at varying lengths, producing different shapes and sizes.
  • Nuclei are visible in cells cut through the center.
  • Cells cut away from the center do not show nuclei.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female presents with significant weight loss and a characteristic rash as in the image. Blood tests reveal elevated plasma glucagon levels exceeding 1000 pg/mL. A CT scan shows a large mass in the tail of the pancreas. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The mass is commonly found in the head of the pancreas

options.label: B
options.text: The initial treatment includes antibiotics and steroids

options.label: C
options.text: The rash seen is necrolytic migratory erythema

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical resection is the treatment option for this condition

questions.correct_answer: C. The rash seen is necrolytic migratory erythema
questions.explanation:
Glucagonoma

Insulinoma

  • Over 50% are metastatic.
  • Typically large at diagnosis.
  • Located in the tail and body of the pancreas.
  • More commonly benign.
  • Small (<2cm) at diagnosis.
  • Equally present in all parts of the pancreas.

Acanthosis nigricans

Necrobiosis lipoidica

Necrolytic migratory erythema
  • It is seen in diabetes mellitus and other endocrinopathies.
  • Presents as hyperpigmentation & thick velvety patch on the back of the neck, axilla, or groin.
  • It is a chronic granulomatous disease that is rare and seen in diabetic patients.
  • Presents as well-rounded erythematous papules.
  • Found in patients with glucagonoma.
  • Presents as bullae and vesicles with a rash over the abdomen, groin, genitals, or buttocks.
  • Also seen as cheilitis or glossitis.

questions.text: Which technique of incisional hernia is done at point B?
questions.explanation:
Technique

Mesh Placement

Procedure

Advantages

Disadvantages

Inlay

(Option B)

Within the fascial defect itself

Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect.

It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible.

High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure

Onlay

(Option A)

On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis

Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured

Technically easier and less invasive.

Higher risk of seroma formation, mesh infection, and skin necrosis.

Retromuscular

(Option C)

Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath

The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it

Lower recurrence rates, mesh well incorporated into tissues

More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles.

Preperitoneal

(Option D)

Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath.

Peritoneum is separated from posterior rectus sheath, mesh is placed in this space, peritoneum is closed over it.

Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions.

Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman has a purulent discharge from a surgical wound after an abdominal surgery performed two weeks ago. An analysis of the discharge, reveals Gram-positive cocci. Further testing shows that the organism is catalase-positive and coagulase-negative. What is the most likely organism?
Which of the following is considered the primary pacemaker for respiration in the brainstem?
questions.explanation:
Zones

Location

Function

Pre-Bötzinger Complex

Ventrolateral medulla

A primary pacemaker for respiration that generates the basic rhythmic pattern of breathing.

Bötzinger Complex

(Option B ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, dorsal

Modulates respiratory rhythm; involved in expiratory phase regulation and inhibition of inspiration.

Rostral Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

(Option A ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, rostral

It contributes to rhythm generation and integrates respiratory signals; it is involved in the inspiratory and expiratory phases.

Caudal Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

(Option D ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, caudal

Primarily involved in controlling the expiratory phase of respiration.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with fatigue, weakness, and pallor. Blood tests reveal microcytic anemia with elevated serum iron and ferritin levels. Bone marrow biopsy shows ringed sideroblasts. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the ALAS2 gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

X-Linked Sideroblastic Anemia (XLSA)

Autosomal Recessive Sideroblastic Anemia (ARSA)

(Option D)

Genetic Cause

Mutation in the ALAS2 gene

Mutations in various genes involved in glycine transport into mitochondria, including SLC25A38 and GLRX5

Gender Predominance

Primarily affects males

It affects both males and females equally

Clinical Presentation

Microcytic, hypochromic anemia; ringed sideroblasts; increased serum iron and ferritin

Microcytic anemia; ringed sideroblasts; variable symptoms

Pathway Affected

Heme synthesis (5-aminolevulinate synthase 2)

Mitochondrial function, iron-sulfur cluster biogenesis

Common Symptoms

Fatigue, pallor, weakness

Fatigue, pallor, weakness; potential systemic symptoms

Diagnosis

Genetic testing for ALAS2 mutations

Genetic testing for specific gene mutations

Management Options

Pyridoxine, iron chelation, blood transfusions

Iron chelation, blood transfusions, supportive therapies

questions.text: A 35-year-old female experiences numbness and tingling in her right arm, worsened by arm elevation. During examination, she abducts her arms to 90° with external rotation, flexes her elbows to 90°, and opens and closes her hands for 3 minutes, which reproduces her symptoms. Which test was most likely performed?
questions.explanation:
Test

Maneuver

Result

Adson's Test (Option A)

Arm abducted 30° and maximally extended. Patient extends neck, turns head toward the ipsilateral side, and inhales deeply.

Decrease or absence of ipsilateral radial pulse.

Elevated Arm Stress Test (EAST) / Roos Test (Option B)

Arms in "surrender" position (abducted 90°, external rotation, elbows flexed 90°).

The patient slowly opens and closes hands for 3 minutes.

Pain, paresthesia, heaviness, or weakness precipitated.

Upper Limb Tension Test (ULTT) / Elvey Test (Option D)
  • Position 1: Arms abducted 90°, elbows flexed.
  • Position 2: Active dorsiflexion of wrists.
  • Position 3: Tilt head (ear to shoulder) in both directions.

Symptoms in the ipsilateral arm (Position 1 & 2); Contralateral symptoms in Position 3.

Test

Maneuver

Result

Adson's Test (Option A)

Arm abducted 30° and maximally extended. Patient extends neck, turns head toward the ipsilateral side, and inhales deeply.

Decrease or absence of ipsilateral radial pulse.

Elevated Arm Stress Test (EAST) / Roos Test (Option B)

Arms in "surrender" position (abducted 90°, external rotation, elbows flexed 90°).

The patient slowly opens and closes hands for 3 minutes.

Pain, paresthesia, heaviness, or weakness precipitated.

Upper Limb Tension Test (ULTT) / Elvey Test (Option D)
  • Position 1: Arms abducted 90°, elbows flexed.
  • Position 2: Active dorsiflexion of wrists.
  • Position 3: Tilt head (ear to shoulder) in both directions.

Symptoms in the ipsilateral arm (Position 1 & 2); Contralateral symptoms in Position 3.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with knee pain and reports that he feels a "catching" sensation during movement after a recent sports injury. On examination, there is localized tenderness along the joint line, and he experiences difficulty fully extending the knee. Which of the following clinical features is most characteristic of a meniscal tear?

options.label: B
options.text: Pain on passive extension of the knee

options.label: C
options.text: Locking of the knee during movement

questions.correct_answer: C. Locking of the knee during movement
questions.explanation:
Symptom/ Feature

Description

Pain

Localized to the joint line, particularly medial; worsens with activities stressing the meniscus.

Swelling

Delayed onset, usually hours after injury; presents as effusion. (Option A ruled out)

Mechanical Symptoms
  • Locking: Difficulty fully extending the knee; suggests "bucket-handle" tear. (Option C)
  • Catching: Sensation of knee getting stuck, indicating loose fragment.
  • Giving Way: Knee buckling during twisting movements, suggesting instability.

Examination Findings
  • Tenderness: Localized along the joint line, typically medial.
  • Limited Extension: Difficulty achieving full knee extension.
  • Quadriceps Wasting: Possible in chronic cases.
  • Special Tests: Clinical tests (McMurray's, Apley's, Thessaly) assist diagnosis; MRI is the gold standard.

questions.text: Match the sign with its associated hair disorder: a. Pseudopelade of Brocq i. Scaly & itchy violaceous lesions b. Folliculitis decalvans ii. Doll’s hair sign c. Follicular lichen planus iii. Patches with scales & follicular plugging d. Lupus erythematosus iv. Footprint in snow sign
questions.explanation:
Pseudopelade of Brocq

  • Chronic and slowly progressive idiopathic condition with no inflammation, scaling, or erythema.
  • Smooth patches due to scarring alopecia.
  • Footprint in snow appearance-spreading patches of cicatricial alopecia.

Footprint in snow sign

Folliculitis decalvans

  • Deep folliculitis caused by bacteria.
  • Pustules with neutrophilic infiltrate damage the stem cells causing cicatricial alopecia.
  • Doll’s hair sign - Multiple hair tufts emerge from the common dilated follicular opening.

Doll’s hair sign

Follicular LP / Lichen plano pilaris

  • Violaceous plaques in the perifollicular distribution.
  • Itching present.

Scaly & itchy violaceous lesions

Lupus erythematosus

  • Scarred patches of alopecia are associated with scaling and follicular plugging.
  • A positive history of lupus may be present.

Patches with scales & follicular plugging

questions.correct_answer: C. Presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy
questions.explanation:
Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

3-30 days

Days-weeks

Years after a chronic, untreated infection

Small papule/pustule/
Non-indurated ulcer at the site of inoculation which heals spontaneously with no scarring.
  • Lymphatic involvement of nodes that drain the primary lesion.
  • Classic form: Tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal and/or femoral adenopathy (Groove sign of Greenblatt).
  • The lymph nodes may coalesce to form a bubo or abscesses that may rupture spontaneously with the development of
    Fistulae or sinus tracts.
  • There may be systemic features such as malaise and fever.

Lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation leads to fistula formation, strictures, and disfiguring conditions such as genital elephantiasis and esthiomene, which refers to hypertrophic enlargement with ulceration of the external genitalia.

She denies any difficulty in swallowing or breathing. On laryngoscopic examination, no significant abnormalities are seen, and one vocal cord appears to be in normal resting position while other vocal cord is in abducted position . A 7-year-old boy falls off the monkey bars, landing on his outstretched hand, and immediately experiences severe pain and swelling around his elbow. An X-ray reveals a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Which of the following features will not be seen if his radial nerve is injured?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of extension of metacarpophalangeal joints

questions.explanation:
Type

Injury

Clinical Features

Low Lesions

Fractures or dislocations at the elbow
  • Cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joints (Option A ruled out)
  • Thumb weakness (Option C ruled out)
  • Radial deviation of the wrist (Option B ruled out)

High Lesions

Humerus fractures or prolonged tourniquet pressure
  • Wrist drop
  • Inability to extend MCP joints or elevate thumb
  • Sensory loss around the anatomical snuffbox

Very High Lesions

Around the shoulder

  • Weakness of wrist and hand
  • Paralysis of triceps and absence of triceps reflex (Option D)

Type of Injury

Treatment

Open Injuries
  • Immediate exploration and nerve repair or grafting

Closed Injuries
  • Wait 12 weeks for recovery before exploring
  • Use EMG if no improvement; if denervation is detected, perform nerve exploration and repair or grafting

Fractures of Humerus
  • Assess for nerve injury on admission
  • If the injury appears post-manipulation or internal fixation, explore and repair or graft immediately

Recovery Management
  • Perform passive hand movements
  • Splint the wrist in extension-cock up splint:

  • Avoid ‘lively’ hand splints to prevent metacarpophalangeal joint contractures

Long-term Disability
  • Use tendon transfers: pronator teres to short radial extensor, flexor carpi radialis or ulnaris to finger extensors, palmaris longus to thumb abductor

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with hypotonia, poor feeding, constipation and developmental delays. The child was born at term with a low birth weight. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be the underlying cause?
questions.explanation:
Antenatal Causes
  • Fragile X syndrome
  • Rett syndrome
  • Down syndrome
  • Cortical malformations
  • TORCH group infections
  • Inborn errors of metabolism
  • William syndrome
  • Noonan syndrome

Perinatal Causes
  • Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy
  • Kernicterus
  • Encephalitis
  • Hypoglycemic brain injury
  • Hypothyroidism

Postnatal Causes
  • B12,B1 and Iodine deficiency
  • Lead toxicity

questions.text: MRCP imaging studies done for a 35 year old woman who presented with a history of recurrent cholangitis, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain reveal the following. Based on the Todani classification, what is the most appropriate surgical treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Todani modification of Alonso- Lej classification

Type I

Ia

Cystic dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct (Most common)

Ib

Focal segmental dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Ic

Fusiform dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Type II

Diverticular dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Type III

Dilatation of intraduodenal part of bile duct (choledochocele)

Type IV

IV a

Dilatation of both intra and extrahepatic bile duct
 

IV b

Multiple cysts involving extrahepatic bile duct only

Type V

Multiple cysts involving intrahepatic bile duct only (Caroli’s disease)

Type

Treatment

Type I

Complete excision, cholecystectomy, Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

Type II

Complete excision

Type III

Transduodenal excision or sphincteroplasty (Option B ruled out); endoscopic drainage may suffice

Type IVa

Tailored to anatomy: extrahepatic cysts treated like Type I; partial hepatectomy and reconstruction for localized intrahepatic involvement (Option D ruled out)

Type IVb

Managed like Type I

Type V (Caroli disease)

Resection for unilobar disease; liver transplantation for diffuse disease (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of cardiac arrhythmias presents with symptoms of allergic rhinitis. The physician considers prescribing either terfenadine or fexofenadine for symptom relief. Which differentiating factors should be considered when selecting the appropriate antihistamine for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Fexofenadine is more likely to cause sedation.

options.label: B
options.text: Fexofenadine is more potent than terfenadine.

options.label: C
options.text: Fexofenadine is less likely to cause cardiac toxicity.

options.label: D
options.text: Fexofenadine is more expensive than terfenadine.

questions.correct_answer: C. Fexofenadine is less likely to cause cardiac toxicity.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Terfenadine

Fexofenadine

Type

First-generation antihistamine

Second-generation antihistamine

Cardiac toxicity

Withdrawn due to risk of cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., Torsades de Pointes) when co-administered with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

(Note: CAT drugs - Cisapride, Astemizole, and Terfenadine have been withdrawn due to cardiotoxicity).

Generally considered safer with minimal risk of cardiac arrhythmias.

Drug Interactions

Prone to interactions with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

Less prone to interactions with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

CNS Penetration

Penetrates blood-brain barrier.

Poor penetration of the blood-brain barrier.

Pharmacokinetics

Metabolism leads to a longer half-life and duration of action.

Minimal metabolism, shorter half-life, and shorter duration of action.

Sedative Effects

It may cause sedation and impair psychomotor performance.

Minimal sedation or impairment of psychomotor performance.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with Stage III B breast cancer. Her diagnostic workup includes imaging studies and biopsy, revealing a locally advanced tumor with involvement of regional lymph nodes. The tumor is hormone receptor-positive and HER2-positive. What would be the most appropriate management approach for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and adjuvant radiotherapy

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate modified radical mastectomy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and endocrine therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Primary endocrine therapy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and radiotherapy

options.label: D
options.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by lumpectomy and adjuvant radiotherapy

questions.correct_answer: A. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and adjuvant radiotherapy

questions.text: A 55 y/o male with poorly controlled diabetes presents with a non-healing corneal ulcer in his right eye, despite two weeks of appropriate antibiotic therapy. The ulcer shows signs of impending perforation with severe thinning of the cornea. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the frequency of antibiotic eye drops.

options.label: B
options.text: Apply a pressure bandage and recommend strict bed rest.

options.label: C
options.text: Perform mechanical debridement and apply tissue adhesive glue.

options.label: D
options.text: Start topical steroids to reduce inflammation.

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform mechanical debridement and apply tissue adhesive glue.
questions.explanation:
Management of Non-Healing Ulcers

Management of Impending Perforation
  • Identify and Remove Causes: Local factors (e.g., ↑ IOP, foreign bodies, dacryocystitis) and systemic factors (e.g., diabetes, malnutrition) causing non-healing.
  • Mechanical Debridement: Scrape the ulcer floor to remove necrotic material under local anaesthesia to promote healing.
  • Cauterization: Using pure carbolic acid or 10-20% trichloroacetic acid in non-responding cases.
  • Bandage Soft Contact Lens: To aid healing by protecting the corneal surface.
  • Peritomy: Sever perilimbal conjunctival vessels to reduce excessive vascularization hindering healing.
  • Avoid Strain: Avoid sneezing, coughing, and straining, and maintain strict bed rest.
  • Pressure Bandage: To provide external support to the cornea.
  • Lower Intraocular Pressure: Use acetazolamide, mannitol, oral glycerol, timolol eye drops, and paracentesis if needed.
  • Tissue Adhesive Glue: Apply cyanoacrylate glue to prevent perforation, if perforation <2mm.
  • Bandage Soft Contact Lens: Used to support and protect the cornea.
  • Conjunctival Flap: Cover the cornea partially or completely with a conjunctival flap for additional support.
  • Amniotic Membrane Transplantation
  • Penetrating Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Perform a tectonic graft if suitable and available to prevent perforation or repair a perforated cornea if perforation >2-4mm.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient presents with the following ocular findings and complaints of watering and photophobia. On examination, there are signs of minimal horizontal lid laxity. Which of the following surgical procedures would be the most appropriate for a long-term correction of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Description and etiology
  • Usually seen in lower eyelid in elderly people
  • Horizontal lid laxity due to weakening of orbicularis muscle
  • Vertical lid instability due to weakening of capsulopalpebral fascia
  • Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis/Laxity of orbital septum

Clinical features
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Horizontal lid laxity

Surgical Techniques

i. Transverse Suture and Everting Suture: (Option A)

  • Temporary cure (up to 18 months)
  • Suitable for very old patients

ii. Weis procedure: (Option B)

  • Long-term cure with minimal horizontal lid laxity

iii. Plication of Lower Lid Retractors (Jones Operation): (Option C)

  • Used in severe cases or after recurrence
  • Shortens lower lid retractors.

iv. Quickert Procedure: (Option D)

  • For cases with marked horizontal lid laxity
  • Combines horizontal lid shortening with Weis procedure

Grade-I

Only the posterior lid border is in-rolled

Grade-II

includes in-rolling up to the intermarginal strip

Grade-III

Whole lid margin including the anterior border is in-rolled

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a long history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is prescribed an anticholinergic to help manage his symptoms. At his follow-up appointment, he reports experiencing increased shortness of breath and wheezing shortly after using his inhaler. Which of the following causes paradoxical bronchoconstriction?

A 45-year-old hypertensive patient presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and a rapid heartbeat. His blood pressure is 180/120mmHg. To manage his condition, a Phentolamine is administered. Later, he experiences an allergic reaction, and epinephrine is given to treat this condition. Which of the following best describes the Vasomotor reversal of Dale?

options.label: A
options.text: Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes an increased blood pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decreased blood pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes an increased heart rate.

options.label: D
options.text: Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decrease in heart rate.

questions.correct_answer: B. Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decreased blood pressure.
questions.explanation:
Aspect Details
Definition Paradoxical decrease in blood pressure when epinephrine is administered after alpha-blockade
Mechanism Alpha blockade by drugs like phentolamine blocks vasoconstrictive alpha-1 receptors; epinephrine’s beta-2 vasodilation dominates
Clinical significance Important to recognize during treatment involving alpha blockers and catecholamines
Effect on blood pressure Decrease due to unopposed beta-2 vasodilation
Effect on heart rate Increased due to beta-1 stimulation and reflex tachycardia
Historical note Described by Dale, illustrating receptor interplay in vascular tone regulation

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a cough and difficulty breathing. The mother reports that the child has been lethargic and unable to drink or breastfeed. On examination, you find that the child's oxygen saturation is 88%, and there is stridor when the child is calm. The AVPU scale indicates a response to painful stimuli only. Based on the signs observed, how should this child's condition be classified?

options.label: C
options.text: Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease

questions.correct_answer: C. Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease
questions.explanation:
Ask

Look

Action
  • Able to drink or breastfeed?
  • Does the child vomit everything?
  • H/O convulsions during this illness?
  • Lethargic or unconscious?
  • Currently convulsing?
  • If any danger signs are present, the child needs URGENT attention.

Classification

Signs

Treatment

Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease

Any general danger sign

OR

  • Oxygen saturation <90%
  • Stridor in calm child
  • Central cyanosis
  • Convulsions
  • AVPU = V, P, or U
  • Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%.
  • Administer Benzyl Penicillin & Gentamicin.
  • Give diazepam if convulsing.
  • Prevent low blood sugar.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Urgent referral or admission.

Pneumonia

Chest indrawing in calm child

OR

Fast breathing

AND

No signs of severe pneumonia
  • Administer Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablet.
  • Give Vitamin A.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Follow up in 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

No Pneumonia: Cough or Cold

No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease
  • Treat wheeze if present - salbutamol for 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

Match the following regulation mechanisms with their respective enzymatic reactions: Regulation mechanisms Enzymatic reactions 1. Compartmentation a. Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase 2. Feedback inhibition b. Negative regulation of phosphofructokinase by ATP 3. Covalent modification c. Segregation of glycolytic enzymes in the cytosol 4. Proteolytic activation d. Activation of pepsinogen to pepsin
questions.explanation:
Regulation mechanisms

Enzymatic reactions

1. Compartmentation

c. Segregation of glycolytic enzymes in the cytosol

2. Feedback inhibition

b. Negative regulation of phosphofructokinase by ATP

3. Covalent modification

a. Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase

4. Proteolytic activation

d. Activation of pepsinogen to pepsin

Regulatory Mechanism

Description

Examples

Compartmentation

Separating metabolic processes into different cellular compartments to regulate their activity.
  • Segregation of glycolytic enzymes in the cytosol.
  • Separation of fatty acid oxidation in the mitochondria from fatty acid synthesis in the cytosol.

Feedback Inhibition

A molecule decreases the activity of an enzyme.
  • Negative regulation of phosphofructokinase by ATP.
  • Inhibition of acetyl-CoA carboxylase by palmitoyl-CoA in fatty acid synthesis.

Covalent Modification

Addition or removal of a covalent bond of a chemical group to alter an enzyme's activity.
  • Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Acetylation of histones affecting gene expression.

Proteolytic Activation

Converting an inactive enzyme precursor into its active form through proteolytic cleavage.
  • Activation of pepsinogen to pepsin.
  • Activation of trypsinogen to trypsin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents for a routine physical exam. He has a history of cryptorchidism corrected by orchidopexy in childhood. What is his relative risk of developing testicular cancer compared to the general population?
questions.explanation:
Testicular tumor- risk factors

Major Risk Factors
  • Cryptorchidism: Most significant risk factor, increasing risk by 3.7 to 7.5 times, even after surgical correction (orchidopexy). (Option D)
  • Family History: 3.1-fold increased risk for first-degree relatives, 6.3-fold for brothers.
  • Male Factor Infertility: Includes conditions like Klinefelter syndrome.
  • Personal History: Previous contralateral tumor or germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS).
  • Maternal and Perinatal Factors: Low birth weight, perinatal inguinal hernia, maternal age at conception, and exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) during pregnancy.

Additional Risk Factors
  • Age: Most common in men aged 20–35; smaller peak after age 80.
  • Ethnicity: Highest incidence in Caucasian men, followed by Hispanics, Asians, and African-Americans..
  • Age at Puberty: Early puberty may increase risk; late puberty may be protective.
  • Genetic Conditions: Increased risk associated with Klinefelter syndrome and Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a chronic productive cough and recurrent episodes of foul-smelling sputum and hemoptysis. A high-resolution CT (HRCT) of the chest is shown below. Which of the following radiological signs is most characteristic of the condition seen in this image?

A neonate on examination has bilateral cataracts and, after investigations, is found to have a patent ductus arteriosus. The baby had a low birth weight and is diagnosed with congenital rubella syndrome. On examination, the retina appears as follows. Which of the following retinal changes is seen here?
questions.explanation:
Congenital rubella
  • Rubella (German measles) is a mild disease in infants and children but can cause congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) if contracted during pregnancy.
  • The risk is highest in the first trimester, especially within the first 8 weeks.

Pathogenesis

  • Viremia is most intense from 10 to 17 days after infection.
  • Viral shedding is from day 10 of infection up to 2 weeks.

Risk of Defects by Gestational Age
  • Highest in the first 12 weeks of gestation and decreases significantly thereafter, with defects being rare after 20 weeks.

Clinical features of congenital rubella syndrome
  • Hearing loss (most common)
  • Vision problems (cataracts, glaucoma, salt and pepper retinopathy).
    • Cataracts are the most common ocular abnormality associated with congenital rubella.

  • Heart defects (patent ductus arteriosus > pulmonary artery stenosis (right > left) > ventricular septal defect)
  • Low birth weight
  • Neurological issues (microcephaly, intellectual disabilities, encephalitis, behavioral issues)

Chronicity and Complications
  • Chronic presence of the virus can cause ongoing damage
  • The risk of progressive rubella panencephalitis (PRP) years later is a rare complication.
  • Less common complications: Growth retardation, hepatitis, bone lesions.
  • Risk of diabetes and thyroid dysfunction

Diagnosis
  • Rubella IgM enzyme immunosorbent assay (detects antibodies)
  • Viral isolation (growing the virus from samples)
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) (detects viral RNA)

Management
  • No specific treatment for CRS; supportive care is key
  • Early intervention for complications (e.g., hearing loss) is crucial

Prevention
  • Standard with droplet precaution in hospitalized cases
  • Rubella vaccination RA 27/3 live attenuated vaccine (MMR or MMRV with varicella) effectively prevents rubella and CRS
  • MMR vaccine has a 95% efficacy after one dose and 99% after two doses
  • Vaccination side effects: fever, rash, joint pain

Considerations for Pregnant Women
  • Immunoglobulin may be considered if pregnancy is not terminated, though it does not guarantee prevention of fetal infection

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital with high fever, chills, and severe headache. Upon examination and laboratory tests, he is diagnosed with P.falciparum malaria. The patient's medical history reveals that he has schizophrenia and is currently on antipsychotic medication. Considering the patient's medical history, which of the following antimalarial treatments is contraindicated for this patient?
questions.explanation:
ANTI-MALARIAL DRUGS

Drug Class

Mechanism of Action

Drugs & Indications

Notes

Chloroquine Group

Inhibits the conversion of hemoglobin to hemozoin in parasites

Chloroquine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), lepra reaction, atopic dermatitis

 

Amodiaquine and Piperaquine: Treatment of malaria.

Chloroquine can cause ocular toxicity, including bull's eye maculopathy, anterior subcapsular cataracts, and vortex keratopathy.

Artemisinin Group

Forms free radicals that damage parasite proteins and DNA

Artesunate: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), including complicated malaria (IV administration).

 

Artemether, Arteether, and Arterolane: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure).

Artemisinin is obtained from the Chinese herb Artesuna annua.

Quinoline

Blocks potassium channels in parasites, leading to paralysis

Quinine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), including complicated malaria (IV administration).

 

Quinidine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure) and used as a Class IA antiarrhythmic drug.

Quinine is obtained from the cinchona plant and can cause ototoxicity (cinchonism), hypoglycemia, QT prolongation, hypotension, and diarrhea.

Primaquine

Disrupts the parasite's electron transport chain

Radical cure of malaria caused by P. vivax and P. ovale (targets hypnozoites).

Primaquine is not effective against erythrocytic schizogony and, therefore not used for clinical cure.

Antifolates

Inhibit dihydrofolate reductase, essential for parasite folate synthesis

Pyrimethamine and Sulfadoxine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), typically in combination with artesunate.

 

Proguanil: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure) and prophylaxis.

 

Sulfadoxine: Treatment of malaria

Typically in combination with artesunate.

These drugs should be combined with folinic acid (tetrahydrofolate) to prevent megaloblastic anemia.

Antibiotics

Various mechanisms targeting parasite protein synthesis

Doxycycline: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure and causal prophylaxis), pneumocystis pneumonia (in combination with primaquine).

 

Clindamycin: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), pneumocystis pneumonia (in combination with primaquine), toxoplasmosis.

Doxycycline is C/I in pregnancy and children <8 years old.

Others

  

Mefloquine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure and suppressive prophylaxis), particularly chloroquine-resistant strains.

 

Lumefantrine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), particularly with artemether in northeastern Indian states.

 

Tafenoquine: Radical cure of malaria caused by P. vivax and P. ovale.

 

Atovaquone: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure) and pneumocystis pneumonia (in combination with dapsone).

Mefloquine has a high risk of neuropsychiatric symptoms and is C/I in cerebral malaria.

Lumefantrine can cause QT prolongation.

questions.text: A doctor is called to testify in court regarding a postmortem examination they conducted. The doctor is asked to present and verify certain medical records as evidence. Under which section of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023 (BNS) can the doctor be held accountable if they provide false information while under oath, in relation to evidence during legal proceedings?
questions.explanation:
BNS Section

Description

227

Defines perjury (willful false statement after taking an oath)

228

Defines fabricating false evidence.

229

Punishment for false evidence, including giving false testimony under oath (imprisonment up to 7 years and a fine).

234

Issuing or signing a false certificate is considered giving false evidence and is punishable under Sec. 229, BSA

238

refers to causing the disappearance of evidence of an offense or providing false information about it.

239

deals with the intentional omission to provide information about an offense by someone who is legally required to do so

241

The section deals with the destruction of a document or electronic record to prevent its production as evidence.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with hematemesis and melena for the past 2 days. He reports long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for chronic back pain. On examination, he is found to be pale and hypotensive. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a bleeding duodenal ulcer, as shown below. Which artery is most likely involved in the bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Gastric Ulcer

Duodenal Ulcer

  • Common risk factors for both GU and DU: H.pylori and indiscriminate use of NSAIDs.
  • Epigastric pain, described as a burning or gnawing discomfort, can be present in both DU and GU
  • Epigastric tenderness
  • Tachycardia or Orthostasis: Vomiting may be due to pylorospasm or local edema.
  • The pain pattern in GU patients: Discomfort may be precipitated by food.
  • The typical pain pattern in DU occurs 90 min to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food.
  • M/C site: Lesser curvature
  • M/C site: The first part of the duodenum or duodenal cap is usually within 3 cm of the pylorus.
  • Artery involved: Left gastric artery (Option A)
  • Artery involved: Gastroduodenal artery (Option B)

questions.text: Match the following Thyroid scan images with respective conditions: 1. A. Graves Disease 2. B. Cold nodule 3. C. Hot Nodule 4. D. Toxic Multinodular Goiter
questions.explanation:
Normal Thyroid: Uniform uptake

Hot Nodules:

  • Increased uptake in specific areas
  • Often benign and indicate hyperfunctioning tissue.
  • Risk of Malignancy: 1-3%

Cold Nodules:

  • Reduced uptake in specific areas
  • Risk of Malignancy: 17-20%

Grave’s Disease: Increased uptake throughout the thyroid gland, showing heightened overall activity.

Toxic Multinodular Goiter:

  • Multiple areas of varying uptake
  • Some nodules might show increased activity (Hot Nodules)
  • Some might show decreased activity (Cold Nodules)

Thyroiditis (Inflammation of the Thyroid): Decreased uptake throughout the areas of inflammation due to follicular destruction.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to the passage of blood in her urine, along with complaints of left flank pain, fatigue and generalised weakness. She has a history of recurrent renal stones. USG confirmed the presence of renal stones in her left renal pelvis. Lab reports show the following values. Based on the values given below, what is the most likely diagnosis? Blood pH - 7.29 Serum sodium - 144 mEq/L Serum potassium - 3.1 mEq/L Serum bicarbonate - 9 mEq/L Urine pH - 5.8 Urine calcium - elevated Urine citrate - low Normal anion gap
questions.explanation:
Type 1 renal tubular acidosis  
Defect
  • Inability of the alpha intercalated cells (DCT) to secrete H+ into urine ➜ Metabolic acidosis
  • ￬ H+ excretion leads to ￬ K+ reabsorption ➜ Hypokalemia
Serum electrolytes Hypokalemia
Urine changes Hypocitraturia, hypercalciuria, pH> 5.5
Causes
  • Amphotericin B
  • Analgesic toxicity
  • Lithium toxicity
  • Autoimmunity (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Sjogren's syndrome)
  • Hyperglobulinemia
Association
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Osteopenia / osteomalacia / Rickets
Management
  • Oral sodium bicarbonate ➜ Neutralizes acidosis
  • Treating hypokalemia (potassium citrate)

questions.text: Which of the following factors plays a crucial role in determining the severity of pneumoconiosis in individuals exposed to mineral dust? 1) Fineness of particles 2) Chemical composition 3) Concentration of dust in the air 4) Period of exposure
questions.explanation:
Factor

Description

Chemical Composition

Different dust types have varying toxicity levels; silica and asbestos are particularly harmful.

Fineness of Particles

Finer particles can penetrate deeper into the lungs, causing more severe damage over time.

Concentration of Dust in the Air

Higher concentrations increase the likelihood and severity of respiratory issues upon inhalation.

Period of Exposure

Longer exposure durations, especially at high concentrations, increase cumulative lung damage.

Health Status of the Person Exposed

Pre-existing lung diseases like Asthma, COPD, smokers and immune status affect susceptibility.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man reports to his doctor that he is having difficulty achieving an erection during intercourse. He mentions this issue has been ongoing for the past year, despite having previously enjoyed a healthy sex life. Which statement about his condition is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Erectile dysfunction is common in all ageing men.

options.label: B
options.text: Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors can be safely used with nitrates.

options.label: C
options.text: Situational erectile disorder means he can achieve erections in certain situations.

options.label: D
options.text: Organic Erectile Dysfunction occurs in men with relationship issues.

questions.correct_answer: C. Situational erectile disorder means he can achieve erections in certain situations.
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Erectile Dysfunction

Pharmacotherapy

Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (PDE-5 inhibitors)

  • Nitric oxide enhancers- facilitates blood flow into the penis and enhances erection.
  • Drugs- Sildenafil, tadalafil, vardenafil and Avanafil.
  • Not used along with organic nitrates- Can cause sudden fall in blood pressure and can be fatal. (Option B)

Other medications:

  • Oral phentolamine: May reduce sympathetic tone and relax muscles of corpora cavernosa and subsequently improve the erection.
  • Alprostadil contains naturally occurring prostaglandin E (vasodilating agent).
  • Alprostadil- Directly injected into corpora cavernosa or given intraurethral through a cannula as a pellet.

Psychotherapy

Dual sex therapy:

  • It was derived by Masters and Johnson.
  • It is also effective for other sexual disorders as well.
  • It means it treats the couple (not individual). Both the partners are involved in the treatment.
  • Couples are taught: To improve their communication and Exercises to increase sensory awareness.

Sensate focus exercises:

  • It has two stages:
  • Non-genital sensate focus: Couples should touch, rub, or kiss each other body parts excluding breasts, and genitals
  • Genital sensate focus: Stage II Involves only breasts and genitals. Subsequently, the couple can engage in complete intercourse.
  • Purpose of exercises is to make the couple aware that pleasure can be given and received by methods other than sexual intercourse (penetration).

Others:

  • Behavioral therapy
  • Hypnotherapy
  • Psychoanalysis

questions.text: The following sign in breast MRI is characteristic of:

A 25 y/o male presents to the emergency after a sports injury involving a sudden pivot on his left knee. An MRI reveals a tear in the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). Which statement regarding the knee ligaments is true?

options.label: B
options.text: Lateral collateral ligament attaches to the patella.

options.label: C
options.text: The medial meniscus is wider anteriorly.

options.label: D
options.text: PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur.

questions.correct_answer: D. PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur.
questions.explanation:
Extracapsular Ligaments

Intracapsular Ligaments
  • Ligamentum Patellae:
    • Attaches from the lower border of the patella to the tibial tuberosity.
    • Continuation of the quadriceps femoris tendon.
  • Lateral (Fibular) Collateral Ligament: (Option B ruled out)
    • Cord-like structure attaching from the femur's lateral condyle to the fibula's head.
    • The Popliteus tendon is located between this ligament and the lateral meniscus.
  • Medial (Tibial) Collateral Ligament:
    • Flat band connecting the medial condyle of the femur to the medial surface of the tibia.
    • Firmly attached to the medial meniscus.
  • Oblique Popliteal Ligament:
    • Tendinous expansion from the semimembranosus muscle, strengthening the posterior capsule.
  • Medial Meniscus
    • Semicircular, wider posteriorly than anteriorly. (Option C ruled out)
    • The peripheral margin adheres to the deep part of the tibial collateral ligament; posterior fibres are continuous with the transverse ligament.
  • Lateral Meniscus
    • Circular.
    • The posterior end is attached to the medial condyle of the femur via two meniscofemoral ligaments; separated from the fibular collateral ligament by the popliteus tendon.
  • Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL): (Option A ruled out)
    • It attaches to the anterior intercondylar area of the tibia and ascends to the posterior part of the lateral femoral condyle.
    • Prevents posterior displacement of the femur and anterior displacement of the tibia when the knee is flexed.
    • It is extrasynovial.
  • Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL):
    • It attaches to the posterior intercondylar area of the tibia and extends to the anterior part of the medial femoral condyle.
    • Prevents anterior displacement of the femur and posterior displacement of the tibia when the knee is flexed.
    • It is extrasynovial.

questions.text: A 37 y/o primigravida with type II DM on insulin is seen in antenatal OPD. Which of the following is not routinely checked on her further visits to diagnose complications of diabetes in her?

Upon examination, the otolaryngologist performs an otoscopic examination, which reveals an abnormal growth in the ear canal. Which diagnostic test is most useful for assessing the extent of her condition and guiding surgical planning?

A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with an open tibial fracture following a motorcycle accident. The wound is 4 cm long with moderate soft tissue damage but no flaps or avulsions. After an initial assessment, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's injury?
questions.explanation:
Phase

Management Steps

I: Emergency Care
  • Control bleeding
  • Wound care: Wash the wound under strict aseptic conditions with clean tap water or saline.
    • Cover with sterile dressing.
  • Splinting: Apply a splint to immobilize the fracture and prevent further soft tissue damage.
  • Antibiotics & Tetanus prophylaxis
  • Pain management
  • Imaging: Perform X-rays to evaluate the fracture and to plan further treatment.

II: Definitive Care
  • Wound debridement: Perform thorough debridement of all devitalized tissue. This may need to be repeated.
  • Fracture reduction & stabilization:
    • External fixation: Provides stability and permits access to soft tissues. Useful for severe soft tissue injuries.
    • Internal fixation: Used for more stable fractures. Becoming more common in trauma centers.
    • Plaster immobilization: For cases with moderate-size wounds where stable reduction can be achieved.
  • Wound closure:
    • Primary closure: For clean wounds debrided within 6-8 hours.
    • Delayed primary closure: For doubtful wounds, observe for 2-3 days before closing.
    • Secondary intention: For infected wounds or extensive soft tissue damage.
  • Bone grafting: May be necessary for bone loss or to promote union.
  • Vascular repair: If vascular injury is present, repair is crucial for limb salvage.

III: Rehabilitation
  • Early mobilization
  • Joint exercises & muscle strengthening
  • Functional rehabilitation: Gradually increase weight-bearing and return to normal activities as healing progresses.

questions.text: A patient admitted to ICU developed symptoms of headache, nausea, vomiting, and sudden onset seizures. On examination, the patient has bilateral pedal oedema. The Intensivist suspected an electrolyte abnormality and sent for serum and urine analysis (given below). What could be the likely cause leading to the patient's symptoms? Na+: 124 mEq/L, K+: 4.8 mEq/L, Cl-: 90 mEq/L, Urinary Na+: 25 mM.
questions.explanation:
Na+

135-145 mEq/L

K+

3.5-5 mEq/L

Cl-

98-106 mEq/L

Primary defect (Hypotonic state)

TBW ↑↑; TBS ↑ (But sodium concentration ↓)

(TBW- Total body water, TBS- Total body sodium)

Pathogenesis

Hyperaldosteronism secondary to massive ascites - leading to increased activity of ENaC channels → Water retention ↑↑ (in comparison to salt retention).

Causes

U.Na+ > 20 mM

U.Na+ < 20 mM
  • Acute kidney injury (AKI)
  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Ascites:

  • CHF
  • Cirrhosis (Liver failure)
  • Nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is diagnosed with malignant pheochromocytoma after presenting with persistent hypertension and elevated plasma metanephrines. Imaging reveals metastasis to various sites. Which of the following is not a common site for metastasis?
questions.explanation:
Malignant Pheochromocytoma

Tumors that have undergone metastasis to Lymph-node (or) Distant site (Biochemically same as Pheochromocytoma)

Survival Rate

5-year survival ranges from 20% to 45%.

Criteria of Malignancy

Malignancy is defined by the development of metastases

Common Sites of Metastasis

Axial skeleton, lymph nodes, liver, lung, and kidney. (Option A,C,D)

Diagnosis

  • MIBG & Gallium Dotate is Best for Diagnosis
  • Biopsy & FNAC are avoided in Malignant Pheochromocytoma
  • Confirmed by the presence of metastases in locations where neuroectodermal tissues are not normally found.
  • This is the primary criterion distinguishing malignant pheochromocytomas from benign ones, as histopathologic features alone are not reliable in predicting malignancy.

Histopathologic Criteria

No histopathologic criteria can accurately predict the clinical course of malignancy.

Primary Treatment

Surgical resection, even if not curative, can offer significant palliative benefits by managing mass effects and reducing catecholamine excess.

Response to Radiotherapy/Chemotherapy

Minimal response to radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Administer hepatitis B vaccine only after discharge from the hospital.

questions.explanation:
Category

Recommendations

HIV+ Individuals

Inactivated vaccines are recommended; live vaccines with exceptions.

Immunocompromised

Live vaccines are generally contraindicated; inactivated vaccines can be administered.

Planned Splenectomy

PCV13 and PPSV23 recommended; MCV4 recommended; Hib vaccine if needed.

Preterm Infants

Vaccinate by chronological age; special guidelines for hepatitis B vaccine.

Vaccination in elderly

Influenza vaccine, pneumococcal vaccine, vaccine against shingles, Tdap and RSV vaccines

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of difficulty in vision in her left eye, along with persistent headaches and occasional eye pain. She also reports trouble with colour perception. Fundoscopic examination reveals the findings shown in the image. Which type of optic neuritis is most likely to be seen?
questions.explanation:
Papillitis

(Option A)

Retrobulbar Neuritis

(Option B)

Neuroretinitis

(Option C)

Site

Optic disc

Optic nerve behind the eyeball.

Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area.

Characteristic features

Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated.
  • Pain on eye elevation
  • RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed.
  • Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc, at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis.

A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids).

questions.text: During Psychiatry rotations, the consultant presents a case study of a 20-year-old female patient diagnosed with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). The patient has a history of excessive handwashing, intrusive thoughts about contamination, and significant anxiety regarding the cleanliness of her environment. He emphasizes the importance of understanding common comorbidities associated with OCD, as they can impact treatment planning and patient outcomes. Which is the most common comorbid condition observed in patients with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)?
questions.explanation:
Obsessions

Compulsions
  • Intrusive and unwanted repetitive thoughts, urges, or impulses.
  • Most common: Contamination
  • Repetitive actions or thoughts carried out in a strict, regulation-bound manner or reaction to obsessions
  • Performed to relieve anxiety or fear.
  • Most common: Checking

Contamination / Cleansing
  • Most common presentation.
  • An obsession with contamination followed by washing and avoidance of the presumably contaminated object.

Pathological doubt /checking
  • Second most common presentation.
  • Obsession of doubt, usually followed by compulsion of checking.

Intrusive/forbidden thoughts
  • Third most common presentation.
  • Obsessed with intrusive thoughts of aggressive or sexual acts without a compulsion.

Symmetry/ordering
  • Fourth most common presentation.
  • Patient needs symmetry/precision which results in the compulsion of slowness.

Other symptoms
  • Religious obsessions and compulsive hoarding.

questions.text: Match the parts of the Papez circuit with their correct functions: Part of Papez Circuit Function 1) Cingulate Gyrus A) Conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory 2) Parahippocampal Gyrus B) Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing 3) Hippocampus C) Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain 4) Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus D) Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space
questions.explanation:
Part of Papez Circuit

Function

Cingulate Gyrus

Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing.

Parahippocampal Gyrus and Entorhinal Cortex

Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space.

Hippocampus

Responsible for the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory.

Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus

Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a painless, slowly growing mass in her left parotid gland. Examination reveals a firm, mobile mass. Biopsy confirms pleomorphic adenoma with characteristic islands of cartilage and foci of bone in a myxoid stroma. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Mostly found in the parotid gland

options.label: B
options.text: Mixed tumours with ductal, myoepithelial and mesenchymal cells

options.label: C
options.text: Radiation exposure is a risk factor

options.label: D
options.text: Down-regulation of PLAG1 results in abnormal cell proliferation

questions.correct_answer: D. Down-regulation of PLAG1 results in abnormal cell proliferation
questions.explanation:
Aspect Details
Location Most commonly arises in the parotid gland (accounting for ~80% of cases)
Histology Mixed tumor composed of epithelial and myoepithelial cells with a mesenchymal-like stroma showing chondroid, myxoid, and osseous differentiation
Cell origin Derived from ductal and myoepithelial cells
Genetic alterations PLAG1 (pleomorphic adenoma gene 1) oncogene activation via chromosomal rearrangements leads to tumor formation
Risk factors Radiation exposure is associated with increased risk
Clinical features Slow-growing, painless, firm, mobile mass, usually in the superficial lobe of parotid gland
Malignant transformation Rare but possible; carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is complaining of heart palpitations, nausea, and facial flushing after being bitten by the insect shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:

Morphology

Feeding

Habitat

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman presents with persistent knee pain after recently undergoing bariatric surgery. She reports a history of significant weight loss and intermittent joint swelling. MRI was taken which revealed the following. What is the most likely reason behind this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Postoperative autoimmune response leading to synovitis

options.label: B
options.text: Fat embolism from rapid adipose tissue breakdown

questions.correct_answer: B. Fat embolism from rapid adipose tissue breakdown
questions.explanation:
Causes of Osteonecrosis

Trauma:

Fractures or dislocations disrupt blood supply, especially in the femoral neck, scaphoid, and talus.

Corticosteroid Use:

High-dose steroids cause fat cell swelling and intravascular stasis, leading to bone ischemia

Alcohol Abuse:

Chronic alcohol use leads to fat embolism and marrow swelling, causing venous stasis.

Sickle Cell Disease:

Sickled red cells obstruct blood vessels, leading to ischemia and bone death.

Gaucher’s Disease:

Lipid accumulation in bone marrow causes vascular compression and ischemia

Thrombophilia:

Increased blood clotting tendency leads to capillary thrombosis, causing bone necrosis.

Antiphospholipid Antibodies:

As seen in SLE, these antibodies promote clot formation, leading to ischemia.

Fat Embolism:

Fat emboli block capillaries, causing endothelial damage and thrombosis.

Venous Stasis:

Marrow swelling increases intraosseous pressure, leading to venous blockage and ischemia.

Dysbaric Osteonecrosis:.

Rapid decompression (e.g., in divers) causes gas bubbles in vessels, leading to bone necrosis.

Pregnancy:

Hormonal changes and fatty liver can decrease fibrinolysis, increasing clot formation.

Radiation Exposure:

Radiation damages blood vessels, leading to poor blood flow and bone necrosis
