questions.text: A 30-year-old female is diagnosed with cervical dysplasia, and HPV testing reveals a high-risk strain. A histopathological examination of her cervical biopsy shows the following findings. Which viral protein is associated with the formation of these findings?
questions.explanation:
HPV is a DNA virus belonging to the Papillomaviridae family.

Tropism: Selectively infects epithelial cells of skin and mucous membranes.

Morphology

  • Non-enveloped virus, 50–55 nm in size.
  • Icosahedral capsid containing circular double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).

Viral Genome

Early (E) Region: Includes E1-E7 genes coding for nonstructural proteins.

  • E1 and E2 Proteins: Regulate viral DNA replication. (Option A)
  • E4 Protein: Disrupts cytokeratins to facilitate the release of the virus.
  • E5 Protein: contributes to the formation of perinuclear vacuoles, leading to cytoplasmic “halos.” (Option D)
  • E6 Protein: Promotes degradation of the p53 tumor-suppressor protein. (Option B)
  • E7 Protein: inhibits retinoblastoma protein, contributing to oncogenesis. (Option C)

Late (L) Region: L1 and L2 genes code for structural capsid proteins.

  • Types: Over 100 HPV types, classified by DNA sequences in the L1 region.
  • L1 capsid protein is used for making vaccines.

HPV Mechanism of Oncogenesis
 
  • E6 Protein:
    • Promotes degradation of p53, blocking apoptosis and inhibiting p53-driven activation of tumor suppressor gene p21.
  • E7 Protein:
    • Inhibits the retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor gene through direct RB inhibition and by interfering with p53 and p21 functions.
  • HPV infection alone is insufficient for malignancy; factors such as co-transfection with v-fos DNA, genetic mutations (e.g., mutated RAS gene), & environmental influences (e.g., smoking, microbial co-infections, dietary deficiencies, hormonal changes) enhance cancer risk.

questions.text: Which indicator is considered the principal impact indicator in the National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program (NIDDCP), reflecting the effectiveness of salt iodization?

options.label: D
options.text: Salt iodine content at the production site

questions.explanation:
National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program (NIDDCP)

Background
  • National Goitre Control Programme (NGCP) launched in 1962 (100% centrally sponsored); NIDDCP launched in 1992

Objectives
  • Supply iodized salt in place of common salt
  • Conduct surveys to assess the magnitude of iodine deficiency disorders (IDD)
  • Resurvey every 5 years to assess IDD extent and iodized salt impact
  • Monitor iodized salt and urinary iodine excretion in labs
  • Provide health education and publicity

Indicators to Monitor Success

Process Indicators
  • Salt iodine content at production site, point of packaging, wholesale and retail levels & in households (Option D)
  • Manufacturing level: ≥30 ppm and Distribution level: ≥15 ppm on a dry weight basis

Impact Indicators
  • Urinary iodine excretion (Principal impact indicator) (Option A)
  • Goitre rate (chronic/long-term impact indicator) (Option B)
  • Neonatal hypothyroidism (sensitive indicator) (Option C)

Sustainability Indicators
  • Median urinary iodine levels in the target population
  • Availability of adequately iodized salt at the household level
  • Set of programmatic indicators

Epidemiological Assessment
  • Prevalence of goitre, cretinism, neonatal hypothyroidism
  • Urinary iodine excretion
  • Measurement of thyroid function (T4, TSH)

Programmatic Goal
  • <5% prevalence of IDD in 10-14 years age group
  • <10% incidence of IDD

Iodized Products

Iodized Oil
  • Intramuscular iodized oil (poppy-seed oil): 1 ml injection provides protection for 4 years
  • Oral iodized oil or sodium iodate tablets effective for 2 years

Iodized Salt
  • Most widely used prophylactic measure against endemic goitre
  • Production level iodization: ≥30 ppm
  • Distribution/consumer level iodization: ≥15 ppm

Two-in-One Salt
  • Developed by NIN (Hyderabad) as Double Fortified Salt (DFS)
  • Contains salt, potassium iodate, ferrous sulphate, sodium hexametaphosphate
  • Provides 40 mcg iodine and 1 mg iron per gram of salt

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with blistering and severe itching on her arms after applying the juice from a black seed, as shown in the image. She also experiences nausea and abdominal pain. Which of the following statements is not true?

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with the eye condition shown in the image. The child reports severe eye pain, redness, and eyelid swelling. Examination reveals an inflamed conjunctiva with thick, adherent membranes that bleed when removed. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Membranous Conjunctivitis

Pseudomembranous Conjunctivitis

Characteristics

  • True membranes grow into the conjunctival epithelium and are more adherent.
  • Removal of these membranes often results in significant bleeding.
  • More superficial, with no growth into conjunctival epithelium, and are less adherent than true membranes.
  • These can be removed with minimal bleeding.

Causes

  • Bacterial: Corynebacterium diphtheria.
  • Drug Reactions: Hypersensitivity reactions, Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).
  • Chemical or thermal injury.
  • Infectious: Mild Corynebacterium diphtheria infection, Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option B ruled out), Streptococcus pyogenes (Option D ruled out), Staphylococcus aureus, adenovirus (Option A ruled out), COVID-19.
  • Inflammatory: Hypersensitivity reactions, foreign body reactions.
  • Ligneous Conjunctivitis

Image

Symptoms

  • Eye redness
  • Eyelid swelling
  • Watery discharge
  • Visual disturbances
  • Foreign body sensation

Signs

  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Chemosis
  • Eyelid edema
  • Corneal edema
  • Mucopurulent discharge

Management

  • Topical steroids and antibiotics.
  • Lubricants improve comfort and rehydrate the eye.
  • Membranes can dissolve on their own.
  • Peeling of pseudomembrane.
  • Topical steroids and antibiotics.
  • Removal of foreign bodies if present.
  • Washing the ocular surface to remove chemical irritants.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the pathways of complement activation?

options.label: A
options.text: The classical pathway is triggered by the spontaneous hydrolysis of C3 and does not require antibodies.

options.label: B
options.text: The alternative pathway is initiated by the binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose residues on pathogens.

options.label: C
options.text: The lectin pathway involves the binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes, leading to the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC).

options.label: D
options.text: All three pathways converge at the formation of C3 convertase, which cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.

questions.correct_answer: D. All three pathways converge at the formation of C3 convertase, which cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.
questions.explanation:
Pathway

Trigger Mechanism

Key Components Involved

Classical Pathway

Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes (Option A ruled out)

C1q, C3 convertase, Membrane Attack Complex (MAC)

Alternative Pathway

Direct binding of complement proteins to pathogens (Option B ruled out)

C3, factors B and D, C3 convertase

Lectin Pathway

Binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose (Option C ruled out)

MBL, MASP1, MASP2, C4, C2, C3 convertase

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with persistent pain in his right leg, which is worse at night and relieved by ibuprofen. Physical examination is unremarkable, with no swelling or warmth over the affected area. An X-ray of the right leg is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Osteoid Osteoma

A small, benign bone tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone with a surrounding halo of reactive bone

Demographics
  • Sex: Males > Females
  • Age: Young patients, but rare under 5 years and over 30.

Location
  • The diaphysis of long bones, especially the proximal tibia, and femur.
  • It can also occur in the spine, particularly the posterior arches.

Pathophysiology

The nidus releases prostaglandins which cause the characteristic pain that relieves on taking NSAIDs

Symptoms
  • Characterized by pain, often worse at night (Night crises), and relieved by NSAIDs (Therapeutic test).
  • When near joints, it may cause stiffness and effusion.
  • In the spine, it can lead to muscle spasms and scoliosis.

Radiology

X-Ray:

  • Dense sclerosis with a small, rounded area of osteolysis, often obscured by the surrounding sclerosis.
  • The characteristic lesion is less than 1.5 cm in diameter with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus.

Isotope bone scans (Best investigation) are positive

Histology
  • Consists of a mesh of woven bone, osteoblastic rimming, osteoclasts, and dilated capillaries.
  • The mature osteoid forms the nidus, surrounded by dense, reactive bone and soft tissue with inflammatory changes.

Treatment
  • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.
  • Surgical excision of the nidus (gold standard)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with symptoms including skin thickening on her fingers, fatigue, and shortness of breath with episodes of painful swelling in her fingertips and difficulty swallowing. RNA polymerase III

U3-RNP (fibrillarin)

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • PAH, ILD, scleroderma renal crisis, GI tract involvement, myositis

Th/To

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • ILD, PAH

PM/Scl

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • Calcinosis cutis, ILD, myositis overlap

Ku

overlap
  • Speckled pattern
  • SLE, myositis overlap

U1-RNP

dc/lc SSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • PAH, inflammatory arthritis, myositis overlap (Option D ruled out)

U11/U12 RNP

questions.text: A 55 y/o male heart transplant patient comes for a follow-up visit. He reports that he has been engaging in moderate exercise for about 30 minutes daily. Despite lacking sympathetic innervation to his transplanted heart, he notices an increase in his stamina and ability to exercise over time. Given the patient's condition, what physiological mechanism allows him to experience an increase in cardiac output during exercise?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased heart rate through parasympathetic withdrawal.

options.label: B
options.text: An enhanced force of contraction via the Frank-Starling mechanism.

options.label: C
options.text: Parasympathetic stimulation reduces heart rate variability.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased heart rate through sympathetic stimulation to heart.

questions.correct_answer: B. An enhanced force of contraction via the Frank-Starling mechanism.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Frank-Starling Mechanism

More heart muscle stretch during filling leads to stronger contractions and higher stroke volume.

Sympathetic Innervation

Lost in heart transplant patients; cannot increase heart rate through the sympathetic nervous system. (Option D)

Parasympathetic Innervation

Lost in heart transplant patients; cannot decrease heart rate through the parasympathetic nervous system. (Option C)

Stroke Volume Increase

Achieved by increased force of contraction in response to increased venous return during exercise.

Cardiac Output

Increased primarily due to higher stroke volume, not heart rate.

Comparison to Healthy Individuals

Less increase in cardiac output, relying on stroke volume rather than both stroke volume and heart rate.

questions.text: Which of the following is a specific objective of Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK)?

options.label: B
options.text: To increase access to prenatal care for expecting mothers.

options.label: C
options.text: To improve sanitation facilities in rural healthcare centers.

questions.correct_answer: D. To prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related mortality.
questions.explanation:
Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram(NSSK)
  • A training program launched by the Indian Government to equip doctors and nurses with essential newborn care skills, specifically addressing birth asphyxia.
  • Training program for medical officers (MOs) and auxiliary nurse-midwives (ANMs) is two days long
  • The ultimate goal is to reduce newborn mortality and morbidity.

Goals/Objectives
  • Reduce Neonatal Mortality Rate: Decrease India's Neonatal Mortality Rate to single digits by 2030.
  • Improve Newborn Care Quality: Enhance the quality of newborn care.
  • Prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related Issues: Reduce morbidity and mortality linked to perinatal asphyxia.

Strategies

  • Capacity Building: Equip healthcare providers with necessary knowledge and skills.
  • Essential Newborn Care and Resuscitation Training.
  • Updated Curriculum and Training Methodology
  • Standardized Equipment and Supplies: Provide clean, functional equipment.
  • Effective Knowledge and Skill Transfer: Improve practical application of training.
  • Focus on "Golden Minute": Quick assessment and resuscitation. Promoting Clean Birth Practices: Adhere to WHO's "six cleans". Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC). Promotion: Encourage KMC for low birth weight babies.
  • Timely Immunization: Ensure vaccination before discharge.
  • Educate parents on newborn care.
  • Effective Neonatal Transport: Establish protocols for the safe transport of sick newborns.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with terminal cancer is being treated in a palliative care unit. The physician is aware that disclosing the full extent of his poor prognosis may cause severe distress and worsen his psychological state. However, his family is requesting detailed information about his condition to be disclosed to the patient. Which of the following ethical principles is most appropriate for the physician to apply in this situation?

options.text: The physician should use full disclosure and inform the patient of all risks, benefits, and prognosis, allowing the patient to make an informed decision about further care.

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: B. The physician should apply therapeutic privilege, withholding certain information if it is believed that disclosing the full prognosis could harm the patient’s emotional well-being.

questions.text: A 9-month-old pediatric patient presents with hypotonia, seizures, and delays in achieving developmental milestones. The child exhibits characteristic facial features, including a prominent forehead, sparse eyebrows, and distinct hair appearance. Laboratory results reveal decreased levels of copper and ceruloplasmin. What is the pattern of inheritance for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Neurological Symptoms

Developmental delay, hypotonia (poor muscle tone), seizures

Hair Abnormalities

Brittle, sparse hair with a "kinky" or twisted appearance under a microscope.

Failure to Thrive

Poor feeding, vomiting, and lack of weight gain

Connective Tissue Issues

Weak bones (osteopenia), loose skin and joints due to lack of copper-dependent enzymes involved in collagen cross-linking

Characteristic Facial Features

Sagging cheeks, depressed nasal bridge

Blood Vessel Complications

Fragile arteries, leading to complications like subdural hemorrhage.

options.text: It is characterized by the presence of pre-existing antibodies against donor antigens.

options.label: C

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of glaucoma was recently diagnosed with primary Parkinson's disease and started treatment with syndopa (levodopa-carbidopa) therapy. The patient inquires about potential adverse events associated with the treatment. Which of the following statements is false? Nausea is the most common adverse effect due to the activation of D2 receptors inside the GIT. Dyskinesias and impulsiveness are common adverse effects associated with long-term levodopa use. Levodopa is contraindicated in this patient with a history of narrow-angle glaucoma. Long-term use of levodopa is associated with fluctuations in motor symptoms. Levodopa increases treatment efficacy with carbidopa.
questions.explanation:
Adverse events associated with Levodopa

Side effects

1. Peripheral side effects:

  • Nausea/ vomiting: (Statement 1)
    • Most common
    • Due to D2 receptor activation in CTZ outside the blood-brain barrier.
    • Treat with domperidone (Blocks D2 receptor)
  • Postural hypotension (D1 receptor-induced vasodilation)
  • Mydriasis (Stimulates alpha-1 receptor in the iris)
  • Arrhythmia (Stimulates cardiac beta-1 receptor)
 

Note: Combining Levodopa with peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitors (Carbidopa/Bensarazide) prevents peripheral side effects. (Statement 5)

 

2. CNS side effects:

  • Dyskinesia: Treat with Amantadine, Levetiracetam (Statement 2)
  • Psychosis: Clozapine, Quetiapine
  • Hypersexuality/impulsiveness
 

3. Wearing off phenomenon

  • Reduced effect of levodopa with decreased neuron number

 

4. On-off phenomenon: (Statement 4)

  • Fluctuating course of improved mobility followed by akinesia

Contraindications
  1. Angle-closure glaucoma (block trabecular outflow) (Statement 3) 
  2. Melanoma
  3. Peptic Ulcer Disease
  4. Psychosis
  5. In combination with vitamin B6/pyridoxine (increase peripheral conversion and side effects)
  6. In combination with MAO inhibitors (hypertensive crisis)

questions.text: Match the following monoclonal antibody;s with their respective mechanism of action. 1. Burosumab A. Inhibits RANKL, reducing osteoclast formation and activity. 2. Romosozumab B. Targets sclerostin, increasing bone formation and decreasing resorption. 3. Denosumab C. Inhibits fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) 4. Rituximab D. Targets CD20 on B cells, leading to their depletion.
questions.explanation:
Burosumab

Inhibits fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23).

Romosozumab

Targets sclerostin, increasing bone formation and decreasing resorption.

Denosumab

Inhibits RANKL, reducing osteoclast formation and activity.

Rituximab

Targets CD20 on B cells, leading to their depletion and affecting bone remodeling indirectly.

Monoclonal antibody

Description

Denosumab

Mechanism of action:

Denosumab → binds to RANKL (receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-B ligand) → Prevents the interaction between RANKL and its receptor (RANK) on the surface of osteoclasts and osteoclast precursors → reduction in osteoclast formation, function, and survival → ↓ bone resorption.

Uses:

  • Osteoporosis treatment in postmenopausal women at high fracture risk.
  • Enhancing bone mass in men with osteoporosis.
  • Treat bone loss due to hormone ablation therapy in men with prostate cancer.
  • Hypercalcemia in malignancy.
  • Treatment of Giant cell tumour.

Burosumab

Mechanism of action:

Burosumab (monoclonal antibody) → binds to and inhibits fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) → ↑ phosphate reabsorption in the kidney and ↑ production of active vitamin D.

Uses: Treatment of X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH) (not osteoporosis)

Romosozumab

Mechanism of action:

Romosozumab → inhibits sclerostin → ↑ bone formation and ↓ bone resorption.

Uses: Osteoporosis in postmenopausal women at high risk of fracture.

Rituximab

Mechanism of action:

Rituximab → targets CD20 (a protein found on the surface of B-cells) → Destruction of B-cells.

Uses: B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL), and autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis

questions.explanation:
Estrogen

Progesterone

Source

Granulosa cells (Option C), corpus luteum, and placenta

Corpus luteum, placenta and ovarian follicles

Effects on female genitalia
  • Growth of ovarian follicle
  • Proliferation of endometrium (Option C)
  • Increase the motility of the uterine tubes
  • Increase blood flow in the uterus
  • Increase the amount of uterine muscle and contractility.

  • Increase libido

  • Thermogenic and responsible for the rise in basal body temperature during ovulation

Effects on Endocrine Organs
  • Increased secretion of angiotensinogen and thyroid-binding globulin

X-linked recessive

Accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate in the mitochondria, which then spills over into the cytoplasm.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman at 39 weeks gestation presents with severe abdominal pain, followed by per-vaginal bleeding. She reports a history of recent trauma after a car accident. The patient is not in labor. On physical examination, she is found to be unstable, and fetal heart rate monitoring shows fetal distress. Immediate resuscitation efforts are initiated. What is the definitive management for this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue to observe and wait for normal vaginal delivery

options.label: C
options.text: Induction of labour by low rupture of membrane

questions.explanation:
Vaginal delivery is favoured in:
  1. Limited placental abruption.
  2. FHR tracing is reassuring.
  3. Facilities for continuous fetal monitoring are available.
  4. The prospect of vaginal delivery is soon.
  5. Placental abruption with a dead fetus.

Cesarean section is favoured in:
  1. Bleeding continues, and the placental abruption is greater than in Grade 1.
  2. Severe abruption with a live fetus.
  3. An amniotomy could not be done due to an unfavourable cervix.
  4. The prospect of immediate vaginal delivery is remote despite attempts.
  5. Amniotomy failed to control bleeding.
  6. Amniotomy failed to arrest the process of abruption, evidenced by rising fundal height or the appearance of adverse features (e.g., fetal distress, falling fibrinogen level, oliguria).

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Insulin glargine at bedtime and insulin lispro before meals.
questions.explanation:
Type of Insulin

Name of Insulin

Duration of Action

Properties

Long-acting

Glargine (Lantus)

12-24 hrs

Clear solution with a pH of 4.0 that stabilises the insulin hexamer; when injected into the neutral pH of the subcutaneous space, aggregation occurs, resulting in prolonged, predictable absorption from the injection site
 

Detemir

6-10 hrs

Modified by the addition of a saturated fatty acid to the ε amino group of LysB29, yielding myristoylated insulin that binds to albumin via its fatty acid chain when injected subcutaneously

Ultra-long acting

Degludec

>24 hrs

Forms multi hexamers after injection subcutaneously and is associated with less severe hypoglycemia than glargine

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with high pulse pressure. Histopathological examination is shown below. The arteries appear thickened, but there is no significant luminal narrowing. Which of the following conditions is the likely cause?

A patient presents with left-sided chest pain, which started 5 hours ago, radiating to the left arm and doesn’t get relieved on taking rest. An ECG is taken immediately which is given below. Which of the following is the drug for definitive management in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Initial management
  • Oxygen
  • Nitrates
  • Morphine
  • Loading lose (dual antiplatelets + statin)

Definitive management

Reperfusion therapy:

  • Primary percutaneous coronary intervention: If presents within 12 hours.
 

(door to balloon time <90 minutes)

 
  • Thrombolysis: If presents more than 12 hours or no access to PCI within 2 hours of presentation.
 
  • Recombinant tissue plasminogen activators: alteplase, reteplase and tenecteplase.
 

(door to needle time <30 minutes)

Long-term management
  • Lifestyle modifications
  • Dual antiplatelets
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Beta-blockers
  • Statins
  • Oral hypoglycemics (if diabetic)

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with an elevated PSA level of 12 ng/mL. A transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy reveals a Gleason score of 9 (4 + 5). Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Active surveillance with regular PSA monitoring and repeat biopsies

questions.correct_answer: C. Hormone therapy and possibly radiation
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Key Points

DRE

Physical examination; detects nodules but limited in early-stage

PSA Test

Measures PSA levels; elevated levels suggest cancer

TRUS

Imaging with rectal probe; detects abnormalities

mpMRI

Advanced imaging; superior for staging and capsular spread

Prostate Biopsy

Gold standard for diagnosis; tissue sampling for cancer cells

Gleason

Score

Grade

Components

Cancer

Grade

Description

6

3 + 3

Low-grade

Cells resemble healthy tissue; low likelihood of growth and spread.

7

3 + 4 or 4 + 3

Intermediate-grade

Cells show more variation; moderate risk of growth and spread.

8

4 + 4, 3 + 5, or 5 + 3

High-grade

Cells look very different; higher likelihood of rapid growth and spread.

9 or 10

4 + 5, 5 + 4, or 5 + 5

Very high-grade

Cells are highly aggressive; very likely to grow and spread quickly.

Management Strategy

Key Points

Active Surveillance (Option A ruled out)

For low-risk cases; regular monitoring

Radical Prostatectomy (Option B ruled out)

Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative

Radiation Therapy

High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy

Hormone Therapy (Option C)

Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases

Chemotherapy

Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the usage of pessary in a prolapse patient except?

options.label: A
options.text: Are a non-surgical option for managing pelvic organ prolapse.

options.label: B
options.text: Can be used as a temporary measure before surgical intervention.

options.label: C
options.text: Regular follow-up is not required once a pessary is adequately fitted.

options.label: D
options.text: Pessaries can be used to treat stress urinary incontinence.

questions.correct_answer: C. Regular follow-up is not required once a pessary is adequately fitted.
questions.explanation:
Types

Ring Pessary, Gellhorn Pessary, Donut Pessary.

Mechanism
  • Provides mechanical support to the pelvic organs
  • Helps with urinary and bowel symptoms

Conditions
  • Patients with complications (stress urinary incontinence, combined prolapse) (Option D)
  • Non-surgical management for inoperable cases (Option A)
  • Patients awaiting surgery (temporary relief) (Option B)
  • Prolapse in a pregnant female.

Disadvantages
  • Vaginal irritation, discharge, infection.
  • Pressure necrosis
  • Regular follow-up (Option C)

Contraindications
  • Active pelvic infection
  • Allergic reaction to material
  • Non-compliance with follow-up

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 24 hours after a vaginal delivery with complaints of severe perineal pain and difficulty with bowel movements. Upon examination, a third-degree perineal tear is diagnosed. What is not done as the next step in management
questions.correct_answer: A. Immediate repair of the tear
questions.explanation:
1

Positioning

Lithotomy position, clean the area.

2

Anaesthesia

Local infiltration with lignocaine, pudendal block, or regional/general anaesthesia.

3

Suturing steps
  1. Start with rectal and anal mucosa using No. 3-0 vicryl or PDS, interrupted sutures with knots inside.
  2. Suture rectal muscles and pararectal fascia with interrupted sutures using the same material.
  3. Reconstruct sphincter ani externus (EAS) with figure-of-eight stitch, support with additional interrupted sutures.
  4. Repair perineal muscles with interrupted No. 0 PDS or similar, and bury knots under superficial muscles.
  5. Close the vaginal wall and perineal skin with interrupted sutures.

4

Suture materials
  • External anal sphincter: PDS or vicryl.
  • Internal anal sphincter: Finer sutures like 3-0 PDS.

5

After care
  • Similar to post-episiotomy care.
  • Specific care for complete tear repairs:
    • Low-residue diet post-repair.
    • Lactulose to soften stools.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Pelvic floor exercises.
    • Follow-up at 6-12 weeks postpartum.
    • Further consultations for persistent incontinence.

6

Future Pregnancies
  • Institutional Delivery: Recommended for all women post-repair.
  • Vaginal Delivery: May be considered with or without an episiotomy.
  • Elective Caesarean: Recommended for women with symptoms or abnormal findings on endoanal ultrasound or anorectal manometry.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing surgery and is given repeated doses of suxamethonium for muscle relaxation. After some time, his muscle response starts to fade despite continuous stimulation. This is most likely due to the development of a phase II block. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of phase II block with suxamethonium?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.text: Match the following with their correct answers. 1 C3a i Decay accelerating factor 2 C3b ii EBV receptor 3 CR2 iii Anaphylatoxin 4 CD55 iv Opsonin

Worth's Four Dot Test for a 6 y/o child reveals that the child sees two red and three green lights as shown below in the image. Based on the test result, what is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.explanation:
Name of the test

Procedure

Results

Worth’s Four Dot test


 
  • The patient wears a red lens on the right eye and a green lens on the left eye.
  • They are shown a box with four lights: one red, two green, and one white.
  • The patient is asked how many lights they see.
  • All four lights: BSV (binocular single vision). (Option A ruled out)
  • All four lights with manifest squint: Harmonious ARC (anomalous retinal correspondence).
  • Two red lights: Right eye suppression. (Option C ruled out)
  • Three green lights: Left eye suppression. (Option B ruled out)
  • Alternating red and green lights: Alternating suppression.
  • Two red and three green lights: Diplopia (double vision).(Option D)

4 Prism Base-out test
  • A 4-diopter base-out prism is placed in front of the eye suspected of having CSS or microtropia.
  • The movement of both eyes is observed.

Bifoveal fixation (normal binocular vision):

  • Both eyes move to maintain fixation and converge to correct for the prism-induced diplopia.

Microtropia with suppression:

  • When the prism is placed in front of the suppressed eye, no corrective eye movement is observed because the image falls within the suppression scotoma.

Bagolini striated glass test
  • Striated glasses are placed in front of each eye at 45° and 135°.
  • The patient fixates on a single-point light source.
  • Each eye sees an oblique streak of light perpendicular to the other
  • If the two streaks cross to form an 'X': BSV or harmonious ARC.
  • If two lines are seen but don’t intersect: Diplopia (double vision).
  • If only one streak is seen: Suppression.
  • If a gap is seen in one of the streaks: Central suppression scotoma (CSS).

Synoptophore
  • The patient views pictures inserted in two tubes, each with an optical system equivalent to a 6-meter distance.
  • The images are moved to adjust for horizontal, vertical, and torsional misalignment.
  • Detects suppression and ARC.
  • Assesses binocular function and misalignments in different positions of gaze.
  • Helps plan surgery for squint by measuring and adjusting for misalignments in various gaze positions.

questions.text: You are intern posted in ICU. Nurse calls you to assist for a sepsis patient whose ECG monitor is showing the following display and she has started chest compressions. Which of the following is the first step in managment of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Basic Life Support (BLS)

Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS)

Goal

Maintain brain perfusion by supporting circulation and breathing.

Maintain cardiovascular function with advanced interventions, including airway management, rhythm correction, and medication administration.

Primary Users

First responders (e.g., EMTs, nurses, rescuers with CPR certification).

Healthcare professionals (e.g., physicians, paramedics, nurses with advanced training).

Airway Management

Basic methods: mouth-to-mask, bag-mask ventilation.

Advanced airway techniques: endotracheal intubation, supraglottic airway devices.

Breathing Support

Rescue breaths or bag-mask ventilation.

Continuous ventilation with advanced airway in place (1 breath every 6 seconds).

Use of Defibrillation

AED (Automated External Defibrillator) automatically detects rhythm and advises shock if needed.

A defibrillator is used, but the healthcare provider makes the decision to shock based on rhythm analysis.

Differential Diagnosis of Pulselessness

Focuses on performing CPR and defibrillation without diagnosing underlying causes.

Includes diagnosing and treating reversible causes of pulselessness like hypovolemia, tension pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade, etc.

Medication Use

No medications were administered.

Administers medications (e.g., epinephrine, amiodarone, atropine)

Chest Compressions

High-quality chest compressions (30:2 ratio for adults without advanced airway).

Same chest compression techniques, with rhythm-guided interruptions for defibrillation or other interventions.

Focus on Reversible Causes

Not explicitly emphasized.

Actively diagnoses and treats reversible causes (e.g., 5 H’s and T’s)

questions.text: A 59-year-old male with T2N2bM0 squamous cell carcinoma of the buccal mucosa underwent surgery. The postoperative histopathology report reveals close surgical margin (< 5 mm) and extracapsular extension in two lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate adjuvant treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Therapy

Indications

Radiotherapy alone

Intermediate risk features:

  • T3 or T4a primary tumors
  • N2 or N3 nodal disease (without extracapsular extension)
  • Perineural invasion
  • Lymphovascular invasion
  • Single node >3 cm or multiple positive nodes
  • Close margins (between 5mm and 1cm)

Concurrent chemoradiotherapy

High-risk features:

  • Positive surgical margins
  • Extracapsular extension of nodal disease
  • T4b tumors
  • N3 nodal disease
  • Multiple positive nodes with extracapsular extension

Specific indications
  • pT3 or pT4 primary tumors
  • N2 or N3 neck disease
  • Perineural invasion
  • Vascular embolism
  • Lymphatic invasion

Considerations for chemotherapy addition
  • Age <70 years
  • Good performance status
  • No significant comorbidities

questions.text: A 50 y/o man presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back for the past two days. His serum lipase is elevated to five times the normal limit. An abdominal X-ray shows a dilated loop of small intestine near the pancreas. Which of the following is the most likely imaging sign observed on the X-ray in this patient?
questions.explanation:
X-ray Features

 

• Sentinel loop sign (Option C): 

◦ Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localized ileus.

◦ Significance: Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray.

Sentinel loop sign

• Colon cut-off sign: 

◦ Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops.

◦ Significance: Suggests localized pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from a rural area has nasal obstruction, crusting, and a history of progressive nasal swelling over the past several months. On examination, nodular masses in the nasal cavity are noted. A biopsy is done and shown below. Which of the following histopathological findings is characteristic of the condition in this patient?

A 28-year-old man is found dead at home and poisoning is suspected. During the autopsy, the forensic pathologist decides to dissect the stomach to examine its contents. Which of the following is the most appropriate procedure for stomach dissection to preserve evidence of poisoning and ensure accurate forensic analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: Open the stomach along the greater curvature and discard the contents

options.label: B
options.text: Open the stomach along the lesser curvature and collect the contents for toxicology

options.label: C
options.text: Open the stomach along the greater curvature and collect the contents for toxicology

options.label: D
options.text: Incise the stomach along the pylorus and drain the contents into the small intestine

questions.correct_answer: C. Open the stomach along the greater curvature and collect the contents for toxicology
questions.explanation:
Organ

Dissection Method

Key Features

Brain

Cerebrum

  • It is separated from the cerebellum and brainstem with a horizontal cut.
  • Sliced coronally at 1 cm intervals.
  • Fixed brains sliced through mammillary bodies, then coronally.
  • Asymmetry, brain shift, old infarcts, focal lesions, ventricle dilation, cortex shrinkage, fat emboli, petechial hemorrhage, and edema.

Cerebellum

  • Horizontally dissected in a ‘fan’ shape.
  • Middle slice through the dentate nucleus.
  • Structural abnormalities such as hemorrhages and lesions.

Brainstem

  • Sliced perpendicular to its axis at 5 mm intervals.
  • Hemorrhages, softening, cystic degeneration, and tumors.

Heart

Inflow-outflow

  • Open the right atrium, tricuspid valve, and pulmonic valve.
  • Open left atrium, mitral valve, and aortic valve.
  • Best for systematic chamber and valve evaluation.

Ventricular Slicing

  • First, slice 3 cm from the apex.
  • Parallel slices 1 cm apart.
  • Rest opened along with blood flow.
  • Useful for suspected ischemic myocardial disease, shows infarction distribution.

Sandwich Technique

  • The knife slices the left ventricle muscle.
  • The myocardium opened like a book.
  • Exposes infarcts or fibrotic plaques in the myocardium.

Spinal Cord

Posterior Approach

  • Long midline incision, flap skin and muscle outward.
  • Posterior arch cut with a saw.
  • Remove spinal processes and laminae.
  • Open dura and cut nerves for spinal cord removal.
  • Lesions along the spinal cord and surrounding tissues.

Intestine
  • The entire length is dissected.
  • Injuries, poison reactions, foreign bodies (bullets), ulcerative colitis-like lesions (mercuric chloride poisoning).

Liver
  • Remove and weigh.
  • Multiple transverse sections 1–2 cm apart.
  • Hepatomegaly (inflammation, neoplasia) or shrunken liver (cirrhosis). Gallbladder pathology (stones, inflammation).

questions.text: A body has been presented to the forensic department for autopsy, exhibiting typically visible post-mortem changes given below as an image, including blanching and a shift of pattern occurring upon handling and moving the body. Based on these observations, what is the approximate time of death?
questions.explanation:
Onset

Begins approximately 30 minutes after death. Initially unfixed and can shift with body position changes.

Visibility

Becomes visibly apparent within 4 hours and reaches maximum intensity between 6-12 hours.

Fixation

Typically it becomes fixed by around 8 hours (between 6-12 hours). Staining won't move after fixation.

Confirmation Test

Apply pressure to the area:

 
  • Blanching indicates blood is still within vessels, staining is not yet fixed.
  • No blanching means staining is fixed, indicating breakdown of vessels and leakage into tissues.

Definition

Areas of the body where postmortem staining is absent due to vessel compression from tight contact with surfaces or objects.

Causes

Tight clothing or pressure points such as the occiput, shoulder blades, gluteal region, and calf region.

Mechanism

Blood vessels are compressed, preventing blood from pooling and causing the absence of postmortem staining.

Difference from Postmortem Staining

It is not fixed and can shift with movement as pressure points change, unlike postmortem staining, which becomes fixed once it sets.

questions.text: A 68 year old male with atrial fibrillation, on chronic warfarin therapy for stroke prevention, is scheduled for elective hip replacement surgery. How many days prior to the surgery should the warfarin be stopped?
questions.explanation:
Medication

Continue or stop preoperatively

Oral Anticoagulants
  • Stop 2-5 days prior to noncardiac surgery
  • Continue in high-patient risk (e.g., high-risk mechanical valves)

Aspirin

  • Low-dose aspirin (75–100 mg/day): Often continued perioperatively in patients with high cardiovascular risk (e.g., recent stent).

  • High-dose aspirin (>300 mg/day): Typically stopped 7–10 days prior to surgery due to higher bleeding risk.

  • Decision to continue or stop aspirin depends on bleeding risk of surgery vs thrombotic risk of the patient.

Statins
  • Continue

Thienopyridines (e.g., Clopidogrel)
  • Discontinue 2 weeks before surgery
